urn:contentItem:60HT-Y0P1-JCMN-Y1V9-00000-00Rally launches Creator Coin cryptocurrency for influencers2020-08-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:09ZLexisNexisRally launches Creator Coin cryptocurrency for influencersDean Takahashi

Aug 06, 2020( VentureBeat: http://venturebeat.com/ Delivered by Newstex) VB Transform Watch every session from the AI event of the year On-Demand Watch Now[1] Rally[2] is launching a cryptocurrency dubbed Creator Coin[3] that will help influencers, content creators, and streamers run their own virtual economies. And while it's all virtual, Creator Coin is a new way for people with fans to make real money. With Creator Coin, Rally will enable influencers to create their own flavor of cryptocurrency that they can use to reward fans and build engagement. This sounds familiar to me because it fits into what I call the 'Leisure Economy[4],' where we someday will all get paid to play games and build careers that didn't exist before.

I'm talking about folks like esports athletes, cosplayers, influencers, YouTubers, livestreamers, modders, and many other people. These are all the sort of folks that Rally is targeting, CEO Kevin Chou said in an interview with GamesBeat. As an example, a streamer could make a Creator Coin and give it away to fans who spend a certain time watching their livestreams. The fans could in turn use that custom-branded cryptocurrency to buy virtual items in a game or purchase items from another streamer. And they wouldn't have to go to the trouble of setting up a cryptocurrency wallet or creating an account. Rally has already set up an influencer platform, Taki[5], that caters to these folks and their fans. Taki's aim is to remove the hurdles between creators and fans and generate new income streams for creators. It lets fans purchase things from creators like video interactions and prerecorded birthday wishes. Creator Coin is in alpha testing, and creators can send an email to creators@rally.io to try it out.Helping creators make moneyAbove: Kevin Chou is CEO of Rally and former CEO of Kabam. Image Credit: RallyRally wants to make interaction between creators and fans easier, and Creator Coins are part of the grease to make it happen. As an example, one of the influencers using Creator Coins is taking payments from fans who want advice about what kind of deck to build for Blizzard's Hearthstone game. The cryptocurrency is based on blockchain, the secure and transparent decentralized ledger technology, and it won't require technical know-how to use, Chou said. It uses the Ethereum platform as its foundation. Rally worked with Chou's other startup, the blockchain gaming company Forte[6], to figure out some of the foundational technology behind Creator Coins. But Forte remains a separate company from what Chou is doing at Rally. Forte generally works with large enterprise teams, while Rally is working with influencers. 'I've been working on this almost two years. And we've built a lot of deep technology,' Chou said. 'It took us a long time to build the technology because of how hard it is to work with blockchain tech. But we're excited to take the covers off, and we have had a bunch of creators just fall in love with this thing.' The Creator Coins are a digital currency that can be custom branded to each creator. They are also the foundational building blocks in an easy-to-use blockchain toolkit that will allow creators to unlock better engagement and monetization models in their communities. Rally's team of execs from Twitch, YouTube, Disney, Kabam, and Facebook aims to make it easier to make a living as a streamer. Right now, it can be an exhausting struggle for people who aren't superstars. Above: Rally was started by Kabam cofounder Kevin Chou. Image Credit: RallyIf it works, Chou said creators will no longer be beholden to the changing value schemes of big social media platforms, which currently keep a lot of the proceeds generated by a creator. The creator won't be subject to the rules of the social platform's advertising/partner programs, platform soft currencies, and subscription programs. Any value built up in a Creator Coin economy is owned by creators and their communities and completely independent of big tech platforms, Chou said. And creators have control. In addition to removing platform gatekeepers and only allowing payment processing fees and transaction fees the creators set for themselves (Rally takes no fees), creators no longer have to contend with the usual fears around demonetization, deplatforming, and censorship when it comes to their Creator Coin economy. And with blockchain behind it, the creator gets the transparency of knowing who holds coins in the community, transaction verification, and scarcity control. With traditional social platforms, creators earn money via a small percentage of revenue from advertising, subscriptions, or sponsored posts. In Rally's vision for the future, creators will be able to grow their audiences and earn revenue by building their own digital economy fueled by their own currency, where they'll be able to offer customized rewards and benefits, personalized digital item collection and trading, and methods and incentives for their fans to support them with donations, all while keeping 100% of the profits.Creators are already using itAbove: OneNightStanz is using Rally's Creator Coins. Image Credit: RallyTwitch streamer OneNightStanz[7] has been trying out Creator Coin. OneNightStanz's community drove more than 200 transactions of his coin in the first five days of his launch by primarily playing games with him. 'We've had a ton of usage, and it's just amazing to see the community is gravitating towards Creator Coins,' Chou said. 'Their communities are just super engaged with it. And so that's been super fun to watch.' Fans can obtain Creator Coins by heading to Rally's website and purchasing via credit card. Additionally, creators can buy their own Creator Coin and award it to fans as a type of cashback loyalty program. For example, some Twitch streamers are giving Creator Coins to fans who subscribe to a higher subscription tier on Twitch (i.e. tier 2 and tier 3 subs). Users can transfer Creator Coins to the creator directly in the form of a tip or donation (no chargebacks), or they can send Creator Coins to other users. Over time, there will be other ways for users to spend Creator Coin. Many users will want to simply hold Creator Coin as a collectible asset, as it represents their support of and loyalty to a creator. Additionally, savvy creators will use Creator Coin as a flexible loyalty tool, using them to identify top coin holders and offer them valuable benefits and rewards. For example, one of the early music creators on Creator Coin, ChewieMelodies, is offering top holders a custom song request on Twitch. Fans often help creators with moderation, video editing, art/graphics production, and other valuable community services. Creators can use Creator Coin to reward loyal subscribers for past or future support, and in the future, there will be more automatic ways creators can set up earnable programs. Rally launched the first Creator Coin on July 29. There were more than 500 sign-ups in the first five days (July 29- August 2). As of August 5, 11 different Creator Coins have launched with plans to double that number by the end of the month.One Twitch channel, DownToQuest, generated more than $15,000 of DTQ coin purchases, leading to a circulating supply of approximately 140,000 and a current price of 80 cents per coin. Longer term, Rally will roll out additional tools for creators to manage and monetize their Creator Coin economies, as well as more ways for fans to spend and redeem their Creator Coin. Creator Coin is platform agnostic. While Rally is starting with creators on Twitch, the coins will travel across all platforms.How it worksAbove: Rally's Creator Coin works with Twitch. Image Credit: RallyOne of the things Rally did was enable a coin to be instantly purchasable, even if there wasn't an instantly available seller. You don't have to wait or go through a long process of hunting down a buyer who will sell at a certain price. For a creator who is just getting started, they might have 100 fans. If you want to buy, someone might not want to sell. Creator Coin uses something called 'token bonding curve' that creates an automated way to buy and sell. You do the transaction with a smart contract (a program on the blockchain) on Ethereum. The coins are in the smart contract, and the smart contract serves as the counter-party so that a fan can purchase coins. 'There's always a market, and I don't have to wait for somebody else to sell,' Chou said. Rally also created the coins so that each creator can brand their own coin.'In our vision, over the next 10 years, every person in the world will just have their own token,' Chou said. 'It's a way for you to encapsulate your digital brand — or the value of your business or brand or economy or just your financial reputation — onto a public blockchain. And we think that's really important.' You could use that virtual currency on any social network, whether it's Twitch, YouTube, Twitter, or Discord.'It's on the public blockchain,' he said. 'It's not a thing stuck in an Amazon server or a YouTube server. It's literally the creator's own thing. You get the keys to your own smart contract.' For the users, owning Creator Coins will be simple, Chou said. You won't have to set up a wallet or connect the account to a source of funds like a credit card or a bank account. That's one of the things that has held back cryptocurrencies from going mainstream. You authenticate for now with your Twitch account and that creates the crypto wallet. You can earn tokens or buy tokens with a credit card in seconds. As for the price? That's up to supply and demand. As a creator, you sell your Creator Coins for the price that fans are willing to pay. That sorts itself out over time. Each creator generates a genesis token or block. They work with Rally to get maybe 50,000 tokens. At the outset, this price might might be two cents per token. The creator starts giving it out to fans and figures out ways for fans to earn the coins. At some point, once the boundaries of the economy are clear, then people will be able to cash out the coins for U.S. dollars or other cryptocurrencies, Chou said. The streamer could make himself or herself the only holder of their own custom coin with their name on it. It can't be counterfeited, as it has blockchain to establish ownership. The streamer can give out the coin to loyal followers and then those followers can use the coins to get VIP benefits. They could, for instance, use the coins to get special access to a Discord channel, public shoutouts, and game requests. People could also buy the coins and trade them for a higher value as the streamer's brand grows more and more prominent. The streamer could cash out the coins for real money or put them back in the hands of followers who earn rewards. That could enable the streamer to make a significant income. The streamer could get people excited by launching limited-run collectible items in the form of digital trading cards through Rally. The rarity of these cards could be verified on Rally's blockchain and could only be obtained by depositing the streamer's coins. A marketplace could form around the streamer's personal brand.The long gameAbove: Rally is wooing influencers and streamers to use its Creator Coins. Image Credit: RallyChou realizes a lot of people have been scammed in cryptocurrency startups and projects. And he doesn't want the same to happen here. Rally will set up rules so the creators don't run into any regulatory problems with the coins. But Rally itself won't be issuing the coins, and so it won't need to worry about running afoul of regulators, Chou said. 'We've done a lot of work on the regulatory front and on a compliance front,' Chou said. 'We are focused on providing utility. We are making sure that this is something that the creators are using themselves. We're not hiring a celebrity to say 'go buy this token.' This is not that. This is us providing a toolkit. It's a little like WordPress for creating webpages — we give it to the creator, and they use it for cool things like creating limited edition digital autographs.' At the moment, Rally is building a community rather than charging fees. Rally wants to be trusted, and so it is setting up rules for the creators so they can also avoid getting in any trouble with fans or regulators. 'The creators themselves cannot abuse the system and run this to do nefarious things. One of the reasons why we also use blockchain technology is that it creates a very transparent system,' Chou said. In the long term, Chou doesn't see himself as building a company. Indeed, he still refers to Rally as a project. 'In five years, we want to see a very strong community and it's decentralized. We want to be able to do for creators and their fans, where no one will change the rules on them or kick them off a platform,' Chou said. 'This is truly your thing. It doesn't mean you can do whatever you want on it. It means the community itself sets the rules. We all want the network to be successful. We all want it to be used by billions of people. And if that happens, everyone's going to do well.' [ 1]: https://venturebeat.com/transform-2020-video-hub/#/ [ 2]: https://venturebeat.com/2020/02/27/rally-unveils-taki-video-platform-that-lets-creators-keep-most-of-fan-transactions/ [ 3]: https://medium.com/p/be36d66ef146/edit [ 4]: https://venturebeat.com/2020/05/17/the-leisure-economy-version-2020/ [ 5]: https://www.rally.io/ [ 6]: https://venturebeat.com/2019/02/21/kabam-and-esports-veteran-kevin-chou-turns-to-blockchain-games-with-forte-startup/ [ 7]: https://www.twitch.tv/onenightstanz

urn:contentItem:5WBD-X1C1-JBCN-414F-00000-00Ramesh Ponnuru: How Facebook can avoid regulation2019-06-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:10ZLexisNexisBPg. 011Ramesh Ponnuru: How Facebook can avoid regulationRAMESH PONNURU Bloomberg

Conservatives remain convinced that the tech industry is biased against them. They point to evidence that Facebook, Twitter, Google and YouTube are staffed disproportionately by liberals, a fact that nobody seriously denies. In a fascinating essay for the New Atlantis, Adam White argues that there is a deep alignment between their corporate culture and the assumptions of modern liberalism.

A nearly inevitable result, conservatives say, is that the companies are more likely to try to suppress conservative content as offensive: taking down tweets and posts from righties and directing traffic elsewhere. The companies deny they have displayed bias, even as admit they have made occasional mistakes in content moderation.

One school of conservatives argues that while the tech titans' decisions may be wrong and worthy of condemnation, it is not government's business to regulate their decisions because they are private companies.

According to this reasoning, people who are unhappy with Facebook's policies should condemn or boycott it. They should cajole Twitter into adopting better policies. (One suggestion has been that Twitter act toward its users the same way the First Amendment makes the government act toward citizens.) Or they should try to start a rival site.

What these conservatives don't want is for government to force the companies to behave differently, beyond holding them to their own terms of service.

Another group on the right thinks that the hands-off approach is dogma unsuited to the world we actually inhabit. The social-media companies are too large a part of our society, and host too much of our political debate, for the government to leave them alone.

A leading voice for this second group is Republican Sen. Josh Hawley of Missouri. His criticisms of social-media companies are wide-ranging. He has gone so far as to question whether the talent they employ would be doing more good in other parts of the economy.

Political bias is among his main concerns. "Google and Facebook should not be a law unto themselves," he has said. "They should not be able to discriminate against conservatives. They should not be able to tell conservatives to sit down and shut up."

Soon after his election in 2018, Hawley argued that the big tech companies are benefiting from a government-granted privilege. He observed -- on Twitter, naturally -- that Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act gives these companies immunity from liability for content that appears on their sites.

They get this immunity, he suggested, on the condition that they serve as forums for "a true diversity of political discourse." He called for congressional investigations to see if they were meeting that condition. Congress has subsequently held hearings on it.

Republican Sen. Ted Cruz, questioning Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, made the same point as Hawley: "The predicate for Section 230 immunity under the CDA is that you're a neutral public forum."

What they're saying: Facebook can be a message board with no responsibility for the messages tacked onto it. Or it can take an active role in shaping content, in which case it assumes legal responsibility for that content.

Those who fear government regulation in this area (and not just conservatives) have pushed back against Hawley and Cruz. They point out that the law also gives the companies immunity for actions they take against obscene, harassing or otherwise objectionable material, even if that material falls under the First Amendment.

We can split the difference on the question of what the law assumes. The CDA does not require companies to be neutral about the political content of messages they host in order to have immunity. It was, in fact, written to encourage them to police obscenity, which is why it's called the Communications Decency Act.

The law was enacted in 1996, after a web service provider, Prodigy, had been found to incur liability for postings because it had tried to make itself family-friendly and deleted some material it found to be offensive. Legislators thought it was unfair and undesirable to punish a company for trying to do the right thing. But it's fair to say that back then there was a background assumption that the companies would not be tilting left or right.

So what options does the government have to deal with the perceived problem?

Perhaps we should split the difference on the policy question, too. The companies are too important to ignore, but government regulation is full of dangers.

It does not seem like too much for Congress to ask that the immunity it has provided be conditioned on some more transparency from the companies about how they decide what content to promote, hide or suppress. One possibility would be to require the companies to disclose summary information about how they make these decisions; another, perhaps easier to administer, would require them to publish a database of content they have deleted.

Before we decide either to regulate the tech companies or leave them alone, let's find out if the anecdotes of bias are just anecdotes, or something more.

urn:contentItem:5W9C-2SB1-DXVP-V19Y-00000-00Ramesh Ponnuru: What Facebook can do to avoid regulation2019-06-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:10ZLexisNexisRamesh Ponnuru: What Facebook can do to avoid regulationRamesh Ponnuru

Conservatives remain convinced that the tech industry is biased against them. They point to evidence that Facebook, Twitter, Google and YouTube are staffed disproportionately by liberals, a fact that nobody seriously denies. In a fascinating essay for the New Atlantis, Adam White argues that there is a deep alignment between their corporate culture and the assumptions of modern liberalism.

A nearly inevitable result, conservatives say, is that the companies are more likely to try to suppress conservative content as offensive: taking down tweets and posts from righties and directing traffic elsewhere. The companies deny they have displayed bias, even as admit they have made occasional mistakes in content moderation.

One school of conservatives argues that while the tech titans' decisions may be wrong and worthy of condemnation, it is not government's business to regulate their decisions because they are private companies.

According to this reasoning, people who are unhappy with Facebook's policies should condemn or boycott it. They should cajole Twitter into adopting better policies. (One suggestion has been that Twitter act toward its users the same way the First Amendment makes the government act toward citizens.) Or they should try to start a rival site.

What these conservatives don't want is for government to force the companies to behave differently, beyond holding them to their own terms of service.

A leading voice for this second group is Republican Senator Josh Hawley of Missouri. His criticisms of social-media companies are wide-ranging. He has gone so far as to question whether the talent they employ would be doing more good in other parts of the economy.

Political bias is among his main concerns. "Google and Facebook should not be a law unto themselves," he has said. "They should not be able to discriminate against conservatives. They should not be able to tell conservatives to sit down and shut up."

urn:contentItem:5YJX-HBD1-JC11-10HS-00000-00RAND: Implement Critical Care Surge Strategies Now to Save Lives2020-04-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:10ZLexisNexisRAND: Implement Critical Care Surge Strategies Now to Save LivesTargeted News ServiceSANTA MONICA, California

RAND issued the following commentary:

As we brace for a surge in demand for critical care for COVID-19 patients, hospital readiness is more critical now than ever before. Facing a potentially overwhelming increase in the number of critically ill patients seeking care, hospitals may need to make fundamental changes in the way they allocate space, staff, and stuff--changes that may have been unthinkable only a few weeks ago.

Let's begin with space. Hospitals across the country have cancelled elective surgeries and repurposed operating rooms and post-anesthesia care units to serve as intensive care unit (ICU) spaces. In addition, in some communities, health care leaders are weighing the possibility of opening shuttered hospitals and, where possible, using available ICU beds in Veterans Affairs hospitals.

But beds are of little value if not accompanied by qualified staff. Patients on ventilators require management by respiratory therapists who are trained in manipulating the machines to optimize a patient's respiratory status, and by critical care physicians who work closely with ICU nurses to make key decisions around medical management. Many hospitals are trying to expand the number of available clinicians by recruiting recently retired physicians and nurses, as well as medical and nursing students in the later years of their training. However, few if any hospitals will be able to recruit their way out of a staffing crisis.

Hospitals could also seek to repurpose staff from other parts of their operations. Hospitalist physicians, for instance, could help manage ICU patients under the supervision of ICU physicians, further increasing critical care physician capacity. Many hospitals are also reconsidering patient-to-provider ratios. In ICUs, one or two patients, at most, are generally assigned to each nurse. This number could be expanded to three or four.

Critical care, however, requires specialized equipment. Some hospitals are looking to import ventilators from overseas, create regional networks to share existing ventilators among hospitals, and use one ventilator for multiple patients. Such care also requires adequate personal protective equipment (PPE) supplies; if these supplies are not available, that will contribute to disease transmission to health care providers and work absenteeism due to fear of contracting illness or need for self-quarantine. Hospitals have turned to limiting use of PPEs in their facilities despite the potential risk to providers, as well as use of cloth surgical masks, ultraviolet sterilization of used masks, and relying on community donations or purchase of N95 masks from construction supply vendors.

But many of these actions run up against barriers that hospitals alone cannot fix. For instance, lack of regulatory processes around the production and sale of PPEs has led to price gouging, creating a cost barrier to acquiring needed PPEs. In addition, the national shortage of both critical care nurses and respiratory therapists that existed even before the COVID-19 outbreak further challenges critical care staff surge capacity.

In the midst of this crisis, there are a number of actions that urgently need to be taken.

Regionalize Critical Care Capacity Creation

Regional health care coalitions--multidisciplinary entities that help coordinate regional resources in advance of disasters and public health emergencies--could play a critical role in engaging key community stakeholders to identify and implement critical care surge strategies.

Individual health systems and states should leverage existing coalitions and response systems to help coordinate regional critical care surge responses. An example at the federal level is the recent $100 million investment in the National Special Pathogen System, which will allow 10 regional treatment centers, previously used in the Ebola response, to treat COVID-19 patients. This system also includes the National Emerging Special Pathogens Training and Education Center, which will assess and facilitate readiness of health care facilities and provide real-time technical assistance.

Health systems, states, and the private sector can also work together to form novel coalitions. For example, the governors of New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, and Pennsylvania have formed a regional coalition to combat the spread of the virus by adopting public health and social distancing policies in lockstep. This region faces sharp increases in cases, doubling every three days at time of writing. They may be able to work together in coordination with health systems, as well as public- and private-sector leaders, to identify health care workers, ventilators, and other resources available in the region and redistribute to particular hotspots.

Indeed, the private sector, particularly tech companies, have an important role to play. The recent announcement of the formation of a COVID-19 Health Coalition, through which 17 health systems such as the Mayo Clinic and big tech companies such as Amazon and Epic will coordinate their response to the pandemic using data and analytics, should serve as a model and inspiration for regional efforts. Governor Andrew Cuomo of New York is in the process of building a tech-based COVID-19 "SWAT team" to include private companies, universities, nonprofits, and research labs to aid in the response.

Move Patient Care Outside of Hospitals

States and health systems may need to erect mobile hospitals with ICU capability in anticipation of existing ICU care capacity being exhausted. In Washington, California, New York, and other states, plans are already underway to repurpose hotels, convention centers, and university dormitories to care for COVID-19 patients, complete with retrofitting of negative pressure capability. These spaces are primarily created to care for non-critical patients, to free up space in hospitals for critically ill patients. As Atlanta, Georgia, has learned, repurposing buildings with individual rooms for ICU care presents a special challenge due to the level of monitoring needed to provide intensive care to critically ill patients. For this reason, it may be advisable to repurpose open spaces for ICU-level care and repurpose spaces with individual rooms for lower acuity care, or for those who need to self-isolate.

ICU-level monitoring also means more staff will be needed. Governor Cuomo has implemented two strategies via executive order that have made 52,000 people available to join the state's surge health care workforce: a call for volunteers and adjustments to licensure. He has also requested that health insurers disclose the number of nurses, doctors, and other health professionals they employ so that the state can begin outreach efforts.

Improve Guidance from the Federal Government

The federal government could provide clear guidance regarding both resource allocation and crisis standards of care for patients in need of critical care. First, the federal government has the unique ability to redirect the efforts of the private sector under the Defense Production Act, which was designed to ensure production of material necessary for national security. While the law has already been invoked to order General Motors to produce ventilators--a step the company was already undertaking--the federal government could begin partnering closely with the private sector to identify current and potential domestic producers of critical equipment, force prioritization of this equipment's production, and provide loans to expand production capacity.

Second, the federal government could play a critical role in allocation of resources, both from the national stockpile and from the private sector through the Defense Protection Act. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) could adjust the way the stockpile is distributed. Allocation is currently based on population, causing a bottleneck in fulfilling requests from areas with skyrocketing cases. State officials from Washington suggest that requests to FEMA should be prioritized by need. Health systems need transparency about this process to improve morale among those at the front lines and to support health leaders in their decision making.

In regards to crisis standards of care, the National Academy of Medicine (NAM) notes that while hospitals routinely use principles of crisis standards of care C as needed to deal with seasonal outbreaks, lack of bed availability, and drug shortages, this pandemic will require a more intensive application. Earlier this month, NAM published a discussion paper providing guidance on how health systems and health care coalitions can reallocate or avoid withholding potentially lifesaving resources as they navigate their COVID-19 response. While the CDC is continually updating interim guidance for health care professionals, which include strategies to optimize PPE, guidelines from the federal government could go further to endorse streamlined strategies to reduce uncertainty and practice variability.

In addition, discussion of medical rationing internationally and here in the United States has been unavoidable due to the pandemic. Washington State has already released triage documents developed with state and health systems leaders, primarily to protect physicians who will be faced with heart-wrenching decisions as the number of critically ill surge. Other states and individual health systems could develop policies to support providers as they deal with the ramifications of inevitable supply shortages. Federal comment and collaboration with state and health system leaders may facilitate the most equitable, coherent, and consensus-driven strategies possible.

Implement Anti-Price Gouging Efforts

Policies to combat price gouging could help combat some of the challenges hospitals face in acquiring needed supplies; governors and state legislatures across the country are already acting in this area. This is especially important because some states or localities may have no prior protections in place for medical supply; for example, before March 20, Massachusetts regulated price gouging only for gasoline and other petroleum products.

Earlier this month New York, following Washington and California, moved to ban the raising of prices of consumer medical items by more than 10 percent of their typical prices prior to the crisis; New York empowered its attorney general to seek penalties of up to $25,000 for violators. While these laws are primarily meant to protect consumers, they may still support health systems as they scramble to obtain PPE and other equipment outside of their typical supply chains, which are becoming increasingly unreliable; state and federal lawmakers should be ready to quickly enact and enforce legislation to address categories of price gauging that hospitals encounter. Additionally, states should consider using regional and within-state partnerships to create aligned purchasing strategies to reduce excessive price increases, as California Governor Gavin Newsom recently called for.

Coordinating actions across state and federal, public and private spheres, and implementing creative strategies now and in the coming weeks, could improve hospital readiness and, ultimately, save lives.

William Davis is a reporter for The Daily Caller, a college football fanatic, and a gelato connoisseur. Send tips to william@dailycaller.com

Author Image

Link to Image

YouTube removed a video of Republican Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul, where Paul named the alleged whistleblower, whose complaint prompted the impeachment of President Donald Trump.

Paul defended his decision to name the alleged whistleblower in a conference call Thursday with reporters. (RELATED: Does The Whistleblower Protection Act Really Guarantee The Whistleblower Anonymity?)

“I've said said all along, I have no official documentation, nor have I seen any documentation of who the whistleblower is,” Paul said.

YouTube stated that videos naming the alleged whistleblower violated company policy, in a statement to Politico.

“We've removed hundreds of videos and over ten thousand comments that contained the name. Video uploaders have the option to edit their videos to exclude the name and reupload,” YouTube spokesperson Ivy Choi told Politico.

The Kentucky senator made waves after Chief Justice John Roberts declined to read his question during Trump's impeachment trial, because Paul's question mentioned the name of the whistleblower. Paul previously urged the media to   report the name of the alleged whistleblower, and has not been shy about naming him in press conferences. (RELATED: Rand Paul Introduces AFGHAN Service Act To End War In Afghanistan)

Link to Image

(Photo by Drew Angerer/Getty Images)

Paul said that he's had “over 200 death threats” in the last week after the president's acquittal, and that people are putting his address on the internet.

“I've been at the ball field when Steve Scalise was almost killed, I've had shots at fired at me, I've had six ribs broken,” Paul said. “I haven't seen any concern from any of these left-wing outlets for my safety.”

Paul continued to rip YouTube for censoring his video, but cautioned against significant regulations for big tech companies.

“What my goal is, is to try to look at barriers to entry for competition, and if possible remove any barriers to entry for new players that would compete against YouTube or Twitter,” Paul said. “As opposed to disrupting or destroying YouTube, or Google, or Facebook, I'd rather try to remove any impediments from their competition.

Senator Rand Paul (R-KY) walks from a Republican Senate caucus meeting with U.S. Vice President Mike Pence on Capitol Hill in Washington, U.S., September 26, 2018. REUTERS/Joshua Roberts

Corporate Participants

* David Tailleur

Randstad N.V. - Director of IR

* Henry R. Schirmer

Randstad N.V. - CFO & Member of Executive Board

* Jacques van den Broek

Randstad N.V. - CEO & Chairman of the Executive Board

* Karen L. Fichuk

Randstad N.V. - Member of Executive Board & CEO of North America Business

Conference Call Participants

* Anvesh Agrawal

Morgan Stanley, Research Division - Equity Analyst

* Emira Sagaama

ODDO BHF Corporate & Markets, Research Division - Analyst

* George Nicholas Gregory

Exane BNP Paribas, Research Division - Research Analyst

* Hans Pluijgers

Kepler Cheuvreux, Research Division - Head of Research of Benelux

* Konrad Zomer

ABN AMRO Bank N.V., Research Division - Equity Research Analyst

* Marc Zwartsenburg

ING Groep N.V., Research Division - Head of Benelux Equity Research

* Rajesh Kumar

HSBC, Research Division - Analyst

* Suhasini Varanasi

Goldman Sachs Group Inc., Research Division - Equity Analyst

Presentation

DAVID TAILLEUR, DIRECTOR OF IR, RANDSTAD N.V.: Good morning, everyone. Welcome all to the Randstad Analyst Seminar 2019 in London. We also would like to welcome all people, participants on the webcast dialing in. Today, we aim to provide you with an update on the progress and results of our digital initiatives as well as a differentiating long-term strategy, and Jacques will elaborate on that in further detail. That leads straight to the remainder of the agenda for today. Steve, can flip through -- and Henry will discuss our operating performance and also how we are freeing up resources to secure competitive and profitable growth and attractive shareholder returns also going forward. After the presentations, we have ample time for questions from the participants in the room. And then we zoom in on our differentiating data-driven enterprise client approach, offering major growth opportunities towards large multinational accounts. And that part will be covered by Rebecca Henderson and Tania de Decker. Then on the presentation of Jacques and Henry, they will be webcast and recorded, and the slides and the playback will be available on our website later on today. Housekeeping: please keep your phone on mute.

And now I would like to hand over to our Group CEO, Jacques van den Broek.

JACQUES VAN DEN BROEK, CEO & CHAIRMAN OF THE EXECUTIVE BOARD, RANDSTAD N.V.: Good morning, everybody. Great to see you again. I think I shook everybody's hands. Great to be in Christmas in London. And someone asked me, "So is there going to be anything new?" Well, we don't think every time something new is really how you build a strategy. We are working on a strategy for the next 5 to 10 years, but very much looking forward to share with you what we've done this year and how we really progressed here.

Looking back October 2018, so not too long ago, we had with quite a few of you for breakfast, relatively small scale, but we talked about a few things. One of our slogans, and still very much true, is stack is easy. It's not about the tools. You won't hear us talk about tools. Maybe 5, 6 years ago we did that because that was all very sexy and look at us and blah, blah, blah, but we really need to change the everyday work of our around 35,000 consultants to really benefit from tech. The workforce scheduling journey that was, one year ago, one of our big winners in digital towards large clients. I'm going to update you on that one. Data-driven sales, how we help our consultants at the right moment, at the right time to be with clients and companies. Talent engagements, we think the most revolutionary thing we're trying to pull off on -- because it's tough out there. People are not looking for jobs or at least less and less actively, so how do you stay in touch. And then enterprise, we talked about it with George at one page last year, which many of you found very intriguing. Since then, I'm still on the one page, but Rebecca is way further advanced. So Rebecca and Tania will share with you what we're currently doing with large clients around the world.

So what are we building? Let me take you along on what we are building. We found out a few things. We've analyzed 3,000 HR startups in the last 5, 6 years through our Innovation Fund. And we've also done -- at some point, we had 400 internal initiatives on digital. Our Belgium business built a fully-enabled mobile temping agency in the hospitality sector. And it didn't work. While it worked and functioned, but clients said it's nice to have, but we still want to have a touch moment somewhere. And all those -- and although those 3,000 HR startups, they don't scale, they don't scale to a level where it is disintermediating for the current sector for us, and we were puzzled by why is that. Why do you all get stuck at EUR 10 million, EUR 20 million? Some bounce up to close to EUR 100 million, then they bounce back again. It is because of the necessity of people, both on the client side and on the candidate side, but why is that so necessary in our sector? We looked at the sector that have been disintermediated. And the sectors that have been disintermediated, the human element apparently was less relevant for the end consumer, so retail banking, travel agencies, bookstores, record stores, whatever. And at the same time, if something goes wrong with those services, it's not the end of the world. If you are an Airbnb and you rent an apartment that look nice on the website but it was in a crummy neighborhood, though we get an upgrade but life goes on. With work, that's different. People change jobs not because of the hard specs, they change jobs or they leave managers. And I want to join companies because of the strategy, because of the culture. And those are soft elements, and they want to talk to people about it. And if it goes wrong, then you're in the wrong job. And if you're in the wrong job, and people on average change jobs 5x in their life, now what? It's on your resume, you need to explain why you want to leave after 3 months that stuff. So people want to connect. We found out through all our initiatives that people want to connect before changing [HR]. At the same time, our clients, through our own digital offerings, will also, though our Innovation Fund, they still referred back to the physical contact at some shape or form. They can be aligned, just to be clear. So that has fueled our current strategy. As you know, we call it second touch. And we're aiming to redefine the human moment in all of our services where it makes most sense.

And what does that actually mean? So for the small, mid-sized companies, which is a core offering every day in what we call market units and staffing but also in our professional units and even in perm, we allow our people, through data-driven sales, to be at the client at the right moment in time. So they contact the company and they say, "Good morning, I'm Steven Vriesendorp from Randstad. I see you're looking for a financial analyst." "Yes. How do you know?" "Yes, we know, we're Randstad. How is that going for you, that's search?" "I don't know. I just posted it on my website, put it on a job board. I gave a competitor of yours a job offer, so I don't know. I'm posting and praying, as we call it." Okay. Well, maybe it's good to have them over. So we are equipping increasingly our consultants with data. So they go to the client and, on their iPads, they can show the local labor market for that financial analyst. So we need to take into account that we have the ambition, and partly you already have that, to have the biggest talent engine in the world. That means certainly in Europe where we have roughly 20%, 25% market share in many countries, 50% to 60% of profiles we know they are in our database or in the Monster database or whatever. So we can show the client his ability to find this person. We have matches at a certain price point. So we say to the client, the last 100 matches we've seen were at EUR 25 an hour. If you're willing to pay EUR 20, that's probably not going to fly, so we need to look at a different profile. Other clients has a job level 8, and we say, well, based on our data, we see that 8 minus 2 also flies, so maybe we can advise you to change your profile a bit. Once we have that discussion and we finish that discussion, we shoot that profile into our database, and hopefully, we get matches. So that's how we are equipping our people today. Data and people, we think that's a winning combination.

Large clients, very much at the enterprise -- Rebecca will, of course, talk way more about it, so I will not -- I will make that one short. But the question we're posing to the client first is, how do you organize work? What do you mean, contingent? No, work. If you're a company, you employ thousands of people. When do they do something that needs to be done? When does a contingent work? Worker needs to do a work where a firm worker, a freelancer, can you put work on the platform? And by the way, what about the fitness of your current workforce. Are they fit for the future for the next 3 to 5 years in your automation? Yesterday, we visited a big financial party, and they're only hiring IT personnel. They're not hiring financial personnel. So they are in a totally different ballgame, and it's worrying for them. On the one hand, they need to shed people, on the other hand, they need to hire people. That's complicated, but again, enterprise.

The most important and revolutionary thing as I mentioned is what we're going to do around candidates. Let's talk data first. Everybody does -- contacts Randstad physically through a website looking for work. We probably match around 30%, 3-0. Another 20% then get matched immediately after. The job is over and we have another job waiting. But then the contact is lost forever. We never had the technological means to stay in contact with that, of course historically, massive amount of people.

What we're doing now is we are creating with several small tech, bigger tech companies 2 sort of instances. The first one is a recommendation engine, you might call that a search engine, so that a consultant very actively, with the most mobile selection tools, can go into the database. But the most revolutionary one we think is the conversation engine. So the conversation engine is a program tool that reaches out to people. It's tech, but it feels like touch. It's a web-set conversation. "Here, Mark, we now see you've been working as a financial analyst for 3 years in the city. And we do know that people like you are then interested in what's out there. Here are a few profiles, people like you, and what they're currently doing in the marketplace. If you find that interesting, I got a few questions for you." So you get updated questions, any training you've done, any wishes you have in a different job, anything you don't like in your current job. And then we also ask you like, "Are there any specific companies that you want to look for? If you want to prolong this conversation, here's the calendar of the consultant nearest you who can then continue the conversation and see if he can give you a next step in the labor market."

In general, people are uncertain. People are uncertain now with Asian labor market. They know as a gut feel that their employer won't take care of them for the rest of their working life. And sometimes they're not happy in the job. And sometimes they have a long commute and they want to change it, but they don't know how to handle that. We will then reach out, and we will be reachable of course for people in our database. So that's what we're trying to build, which again is data, tech and people throughout every market we're in.

Sorry. So I'm now on Slide 5. For the people on the webcast, I've not been on any slides yet. I just told you the story of our strategy.

Slide 5. Our core values, they are roughly 45 years old, very much applicable today. Most of our workforce at Randstad is a millennial and they're purpose-driven. They want to make a difference, and their values are alive every after work. Our mission is shaping the world of work. The labor market is inherently mismatched, both from a legal point of view and increasingly from a capabilities and demand point of view. And we have an ambition to shape that world of work. That mission is roughly 15 years old.

Our purpose is probably 2, 3 years old, supporting people and organization and realizing their true potential. The locals in the job, we have maybe something better for you.

And our positioning is Human Forward, and I'll elaborate a little bit more on that one.

I'll move to Slide 6. On the bottom, we are future-proofing Randstad. We think, as an executive board, we need to create a company. We're going to be 60 years old next year, as you know. It's viable for the next 50. So definitely long-term value for all stakeholders, although we don't operate from a stakeholder perspective, we operate from a -- from a stakeholder perspective, not just a shareholder perspective.

Growth leader, consistently above market. We have outperformed many markets, but actually we think it's not good enough. We want to grow faster over time.

Superior valuation. I'll show you what that means a little bit later. And of course, a strong focus on the return on invested capital.

Human Forward, left part of the slide. We make promises. We launched this 2 years ago, and we make promises to our stakeholders: transparency, guidance and proactivity. We're a services business and services is inherently invisible. Our candidates, our clients don't know what we're doing on their behalf, and that's why they're always a bit worried. But for example, in our Youplan offering, the client has real-time insight every day in its planning. So he knows if everybody is there and is going to show up for the shift on Monday morning. That gives them ease of mind. For candidates, we want to see -- or want to show them where they are in the job search.

Transparency: You know what Randstad is doing for you.

Guidance, very much in the enterprise story, guiding the clients on their, what we call, total talent journey. But also the candidates, if you don't have a job, you're unhappy in your job, you're looking for a different job. And we see massive changes in the work space. We're taking bankers to education. We're taking people from retail into health care. That is happening, and that should be happening in the future of the labor market.

And proactivity, the sales goal from Randstad in the not-too-distant future is going to be, "Dear customer, our data tells us you will be needing this profile 3 months from now." "Oh no, I don't know." "Well, we've analyzed your patterns. We think it's going to happen. And the good news is our data also tells us we have 2 people that fit the profile that are eligible to start with you within those 3 months." Do that once, do that twice, you're set for life.

Our winning capabilities, and I will not go through all of that, but very much what we bring to our 38,000 employees, equipping them to be winning in the labor market.

And lastly our strategic priorities, but I have those on the next slide, so I'll take you to Slide 10. Embed the digital transformation. Maybe, and I hope so, the story I just told you sounds good, to only contact customers at the right moment in time, to only engage with candidates when they are looking for a job. But the change for our consultants is actually quite big. First of all, we sort of bring them to customers and prospects that you don't turn in one conversation. They work with competition. It takes time. So we go from a more transactional sales to a longer-term 3- to 5-conversation sale. That's due for our consultants. For the candidates, again, we are historically as a company, as a sector by the way, order-driven. We go out, we go to a company. We -- they have -- they need -- they're searching for someone. We find a candidate, we make the match. And what I just described, because often we'll have many candidates in our calendar or his calendar, that there's something better for me, but that might not be an open job order. So they need to go into sales with the candidate in mind which, again, is a different way of selling. So this takes time. And that's why we say tech is easy, change is hard to really embed. And that's not a technical term, it's more of a cultural term, a way of working term, and that's the digital transformation.

Build a stronger one Randstad. Our top 100 management spent the last half year with London business school. Actually here, on a specifically defined course: "Randstad Strategy, Academia from a London Business School, How to Compete in a Digitally -- in a Digital World." Because for everybody at Randstad, certainly management, things are changing. We have global businesses, you need to lead digital processes. But at the same time, we're becoming more global, so we're going to build a stronger One Randstad to sort of take out costs, which is not very valuable at the front-end, buying because we're just bigger, sharing IT resources. HENRY R. SCHIRMER: Yes, I will, I will -- I'll not give you too many numbers, but more a principle. Dynamics we have in the U.S. market, the strength of the team, but also the margin profile we see that I think we can give more investment as allocated to the U.S. because that will improve the mix. It might well be that the margin will go slightly down in the U.S. but overall actually there will be positive mix effect. So it will hopefully pay for itself. Good news is we don't need to make a decision of, say, there's a boatload of money and good, but we can kind of feel and ease into that and say, "hey, that works. [Die down, die down] to that."

So it's more the principle of securing that investment to accelerate the growth. And hopefully then if we're standing here in 2, 4, 6 years, we can say our portfolio has shifted from X to Y.

JACQUES VAN DEN BROEK: Yes. And that's also where the EUR 120 million plays with investments. So when we talk about freeing up money in the broad sense of the company, then the U.S. certainly is one of those places we would like to invest. So there's a bit of a time thing. We first need to get that money out and then put it into to the U.S.

HENRY R. SCHIRMER: So we actually -- we play a bigger role as an executive board to dynamically allocate resources, where in the past it was probably not as strong.

MARC ZWARTSENBURG: And are there specific regions in the U.S where you want to focus on?

JACQUES VAN DEN BROEK: No. Not really. Of course, there are some regions where we're stronger than other regions. Karen?

KAREN L. FICHUK, MEMBER OF EXECUTIVE BOARD & CEO OF NORTH AMERICA BUSINESS, RANDSTAD N.V.: No, I think it's more in line of business, like you mentioned. Hi, everybody. I'm Karen Fichuk, new to the company, but I have responsibility for the U.S. and the topic.

So I think you mentioned the line of businesses. So definitely the technology sector, definitely the solutions business within technology. Canada is one, so we have expanded it to be North America. We have a very strong leadership team there who is poised for growth, given the investments. We have some nice niche businesses that we'd like to organically invest in. And then beyond the lines of business, I think digital and data competencies are also an area of investment for us to fuel the growth opportunity.

And you mentioned the RAS business. We've had a record year of wins. So that will be an area that we need to fund.

JACQUES VAN DEN BROEK: Building on strength there. So Marc, in a way, we do, for every company, we always have plans in place. And then we'll just see what markets are doing, what we can allow, at which speed we want to go. Because for us, it's the push of a button in a way. Again, we also need to balance the short and the longer term.

HANS PLUIJGERS, HEAD OF RESEARCH OF BENELUX, KEPLER CHEUVREUX, RESEARCH DIVISION: Hans Pluijgers, Kepler Cheuvreux, 2 questions from my side. JACQUES VAN DEN BROEK: So you'll take the second one? I'll take the first one. There are also a lot of tech companies that have high valuation and they make no profit. So the relationship between profit and valuation is in a lot of ways very skewed. It's almost unsexy to make profit in that valuation space. We very much feel that it should fuel faster growth. Faster growth at similar, slightly better profitability because that's also how you invest. Of course if we invest less, we grow less, we make more money. If -- I'm not quoting a number here, but once we get to accelerating, monetizing the data, we can probably get to 10%, most growth drivers from consolidation being the enterprise part, and probably small perm, that sort of thing. HENRY R. SCHIRMER: I think you've answered already. But it's all -- we all strongly believe in that the best thing for them is growth and profitable and competitive growth, those things always need to come together.

JACQUES VAN DEN BROEK: Yes. And the 2 other pockets apart from organic growth is investing in digital, where we think it makes sense to speed it up. And the other one is of course the top 100 brand. We do think branding is interesting. So we're spending EUR 120 million in branding now. I think we first need to take out branding cost that we think is old and doesn't really generate or support our strategy. And then we're going to invest in way more online data-driven marketing that gives direct feel and direct support to our people outside and also our candidate reach. So that's a program in place.

We hope that, that's always said if you ask someone to help you to build a strategy, there's always money involved. So that's also on the shelf. And there, we don't have a plan. In the U.S., we have a plan; in Japan, we have plan. But on marketing, that's work in progress. So we'll share that with you once we know more, probably somewhere second half next year.

ANVESH AGRAWAL, EQUITY ANALYST, MORGAN STANLEY, RESEARCH DIVISION: This is Anvesh Agrawal from Morgan Stanley. Two questions. First, just looking at your Tech & Touch strategy and the mix of the business. So I presume that touch is more needed in perm and professional level rather than probably at blue collar admin-level jobs.

JACQUES VAN DEN BROEK: And why do you think that's the case?

ANVESH AGRAWAL: Well, just probably there is more passive candidates there. And also the decisioning from the company's side is probably (inaudible) levels are higher and it's more strategic rather than filling up the shifts that you get at the lower end. So if we keep that in mind, then do you think the tech disintermediation can kind of still hit you at the blue collar? Or at the admin-level job? And how do you kind of plan to protect against that?

JACQUES VAN DEN BROEK: Yes. Great question. And part of what you're saying is true. So same for me, sometimes. Yes, absolutely. We use technology to engage professionals because they're in a job. And they're not going to update their resume just because we offer them a job. So call it the technology-driven conversation is a different conversation. But we use tech, certainly a lot in Youplan and workforce scheduling to have a very quick, call it, engagement. The very quick processing of blue collar people because blue collar people are all online nowadays. And in a way, they're also in a job. So yes, call them blue collar is more geared towards call it leverage, but not only. And in professionals, absolutely more about engaging. And therefore, we do feel [at along the] bottom too in enterprise, fairly fragmented professionals market, and in small perm; very fragmented, we can take share there.

ANVESH AGRAWAL: And just on the ability to leverage your data-driven capabilities and kind of implementing that scale, we can see the advantage you have probably versus the start-ups and the smaller players. But versus your global counterparts who have the same access to the database, where do you think you are positioned differently? Or what is your competitive advantage?

JACQUES VAN DEN BROEK: Of course, our database is way bigger. That's the reason why we bought Monster. We're very much connecting those databases together, where Rebecca and the team can now show all relevant data around a certain profile and group of profiles at a way bigger scale. So that's one.

The second one is that we allow all our consultants that are in the 6 to 7 markets where Monster is still a dominant player, that they look into both databases. So there, we have very much an advantage.

But let me share with you, when you talk about competition, what -- and I've come full circle. We as a company strategically have come full circle in terms of who is threatening us. So if you would have asked me 5 years ago, I would have said start-ups or big tech. Now start-ups are not scaling. And big tech does something in our space, but they stay on the outskirts. Google is about search, but it's not about selection. It's not about induction. It's not about -- if you look at our funnel and you know the picture, they stay on the outside. So you need to play with them. You need to know SEO. You need to know how they work, because otherwise you'll be lost. They're more a playing field than as a competitor. But the biggest competitor is our client. If you look at the most mature market, which is the U.S., certainly old style MSP programs and Rebecca will, of course, allude to it. When you have the old MSP model, which is just putting in an off-the-shelf commoditized EMS tool, and then squeezing margins in competition, that's not going to work anymore. So we knew that 5, 6 years ago. But those clients, they spend -- if they have 200 million spend on the management and they give suppliers, whatever, 30 million to handle that, you say, "So what can we do with 30 million?" for them, technology is also commoditized. So that's why we have way richer approaches now. But yes, the real big, big animals with great employer brands, why outsource? That's the biggest threat for us. And that's why also, we want to show you enterprise and what we're doing because we do feel we're attractive for a large group of those.

GEORGE NICHOLAS GREGORY, RESEARCH ANALYST, EXANE BNP PARIBAS, RESEARCH DIVISION: It's George Gregory from Exane BNP Paribas. Just one please, and it's on the candidate pool, specifically Monster. You talk about future-proofing your business. What is actually happening to the size and quality of your candidate pool? And to what extent does the trend -- the revenue trend, within Monster drive that? Can you improve, grow that candidate pool without -- despite, I suppose, the trend, the continued downward trend in Monster?

JACQUES VAN DEN BROEK: Yes. So the quality of the candidate pool, if you have a phone number or an e-mail address, people are accessible. So that's not the issue, both in the Monster historic database and the Randstad historic database. So we are running constantly trials to see if we can still reach these people. And you can technically reach almost all of these people, but that's not the issue. The issue is, can you engage them to come back? Can you engage them in having a conversation on where they are in the marketplace right now and if they want to engage with us anymore again? And the more people are, call it, comfortable in the marketplace, the tougher that is, so to say.

So hence, what are we doing? And of course, you need to have a lot of new people coming in all the time. So hence, the investments we're doing, both in Monster and Randstad because it's probably important that we, in the first 2 years of owning Monster, we try to revive the old job board positioning. And a little over a year ago, with Rebecca also taking the reins, we now see Monster way more as a concept within the total Randstad. What does that mean? We're investing in mobile so that people leave their applications. You have a lot of traffic on Monster, but relatively we think we can improve the apply starts, as we call them. In an old job board model, an apply start would then be something that you sell to a job boarding client. And a job boarding client is actually a client that does recruiting himself. So the Indeeds and the Monsters of this world, they are aiming at the full chart that Henry just showed.

We are in a different segment, so to say. We operate for the clients that work with us and want to know the best candidates in there. But then we need to fuel -- this is tens of millions of people, still, because although Monster of course, it has been a struggling business for years even before we owned it. But it's still the second most popular brand in the U.S. But what you see is that they attract mostly the 30-plus historically. So now our marketing investments, we call it the sexiness of the mobile engagement, needs to be fueled towards young people to make it relevant. But the offer is not going to be for Monster or for Randstad. "Come with us and someone might call you," because that's an old model job board. In future is going to be "Come with us, become part of our universe, and we'll support you throughout your whole working life." That's a different way of working. By the way, a lot of, call it, value out of Monster is being generated within Randstad. Funny enough, we cannot really value that. We don't know really when someone has come from the Monster database or the Randstad database. This will increase over time, but we don't know yet.

Another investment we're doing in Monster is e-commerce. So Monster still had a lot of people selling physically into small clients. At Randstad years ago, we segmented that out. We don't visit small clients. So we're now putting in an e-commerce platform that these companies can buy that online and that we can shift our salespeople towards richer clients. So a lot of work. But yes, the value of that also historic database, both in Randstad and Monster, is very much alive. But we need to work on it.

GEORGE NICHOLAS GREGORY: Is there any correlation between Monster revenues and the, I guess, it's difficult to measure the quality of the candidate pool, but I suppose what I'm trying to get to is, do you think that the quality of that candidate pool is ultimately still declining, and you've yet to hit that inflection point where it's starting to grow in value?

JACQUES VAN DEN BROEK: It's very tough to talk about the quality of the candidate pool because it all depends on how do you define quality. So we see a lot of clients by the way, in general when we analyze their recruitment process, even if they work with Monster or Indeed or LinkedIn. They spend a lot of time connecting with people. So the old job board model that also Monster had is invest in marketing, get massive amounts of people and then I'm going to sell it to you, which is basically the model of a newspaper. So the basic model of a job board is a newspaper model. I got this newspaper, it's read by so many people, you put in an ad, many people read it, the chance is high. But in my company, we think the whole talent play is way more sophisticated nowadays. Monster was late to go to pay per click, pay per candidate. So it's not that Monster's success, if you have 500 million people in the database with a very -- limited profile, we want to get to richer. So we need to get back to them with this conversation I just mentioned. Like "George, we've not been in touch for 8 years. It's great that I can still know where you are. Can we take this forward?" So quality, we think in general, our quality is going to be way better. It's way more than our peers. It's way less than a LinkedIn or an Indeed, but it's a different way of looking at the world.

RAJESH KUMAR, ANALYST, HSBC, RESEARCH DIVISION: Rajesh Kumar from HSBC. Just on Slide 24, you've shown very interestingly that the Inhouse revenue CAGR has been almost 3x that of rest of the business. What impact has it had on your margins?

JACQUES VAN DEN BROEK: Yes, that's the good news there. So Inhouse is low-margin business but the highest conversion.
